caption: To give my wife a belly full of cheese before a business trip, I decided to play around with a few recipes to create this delicious Crabby Mac ‘n Cheese. I started with Good Eats’ Stove Top Mac-n-Cheese recipe but added added some flake crab meat as I folded the noodles and into the cheese mix. Once in my cast iron skillet, I topped the dish with some olive oil coated panko bread crumbs and a little gruyere cheese. That sat under the broiler for about a minute to get crispy and then came out a glorious cheesy dish!!

For a meal with friends, I decided to throw together one of my latest experimental recipes: Cheesy Chard Enchiladas. I prepared Eatingwell’s Chipotle Cheddar Chard but used canned chipotles in adobo sauce for a smoky bite and rainbow chard for a lil’ color. I rolled the greens up into some sprouted grain tortillas and laid them on a bed of red enchilada sauce, covered them with more sauce and then sprinkled sharp cheddar cheese on top. After 20 minutes in oven, they were deeeelicious!
I tried out Eatingwell’s Egyptian Edamame a couple weeks ago for a quick meal and just got a chance to process the photo today. From what I remember it was pretty tasty.

To meet my wife’s weekly pea quota, I decided to try out the Curried Pea Frittata with Fresh Tomato Chutney recipe from Epicurious and was quite pleased with the results. I ended up using a yellow onion instead green, gruyere cheese instead of parmesan and I also added a bit of chili pepper flakes for my usual kick.

While the rest of the world was watching football tonight, I was watching a delicious dry rub soak into some wild sockeye salmon fillets. Following Good Eats’ Broiled Sockeye Salmon with Citrus Glaze recipe, I tossed a few salmon fillets under the broiler for a few minutes before letting them set for 10. To bring together a meal, I laid the salmon on top of a bed of couscous tossed in a quick balsamic vinaigrette and added a little steamed broccoli on the side. Fantastic!

Since moving to New York, I’ve been dying to create my own New England Clam Chowder, so tonight I whipped up a variation of the Good Eats recipe. I used my stick blender to puree a hot mix of diced potatoes, chopped clams, onion cooked in bacon fat and whole milk. Once everything was thick and chunky, I folded in some more chopped clams that had been steamed and shucked my hand. I garnished the dish with parsley, plain yogurt and bacon bits. CHOWDAH!!

For a spicy winter meal, I decided to try out a variation of EatingWell’s Delicata Squash & Tofu Curry. I roasted the tofu instead of pan frying it, I played around a bit with the spice ratios and then I used regular coconut milk instead of the ‘lite’ to keep things rich. Definitely a meal to repeat before winter’s end.

We’ve had a busy few weeks so our meals have been pretty quick. For a fast vegan meal this week, I tossed together EatingWell’s Pear-Quinoa Salad. It was a great excuse to invest in some pomegranate red wine vinegar and provided a nutritious meal in under 30 minutes.

Tonight I decided to just wing it and throw together a meal without a recipe. I started with salting and peppering a few fillets of rainbow trout before drizzling them with freshly squeezed lemon juice. After they got to room temp, I tossed the fillets in a bit of flour with cayenne, curry powder and garlic powder then pan fried them with butter. For a base, I laid down a spicy curried mix of quinoa, onions, carrots and chopped kale. Delicious!

I picked up a handsome acorn squash from my local farmers market and I decided to put him to good work in EatingWell’s Acorn Squash Stuffed with Chard and White Beans. I followed the advice of a few reviewers and roasted the squash halves instead of microwaving them. Then the squash halves were stuffed with a hot mix of red chard, onion, garlic, cayenne pepper, tomato paste, white beans and chopped kalamata olives and then topped with parmesan cheese and panko bread crumbs tossed in olive oil. I threw the goods under the broiler until they were golden brown and delicious and then we went to tasty-town. Great recipe!

For my first full meal in my new kitchen, I decided to take advantage of the fresh seafood in our new locale and try EatingWell’s Seared Scallops with Crispy Leeks. I played around a bit with the spices listed, but stayed fairly true to the recipe. I’m usually not a huge fan of sea scallops, but this recipe hit the spot.

Red meat needed to happen tonight so I grabbed a pair of New York strip steaks, rubbed ‘em down with some spice and tossed them on the grill. After flipping those bad boys, I laid down some sliced mushrooms and Whole Foods’ jalapeno jack cheese to melt all over that meaty goodness. To keep things hearty, I tossed some roasted red potatoes on the side and for greens, some steamed asparagus did well. That was awesome…

Since I tasted my cousin April’s amazing tofu casserole this summer, I’ve been trying to chase down a similar recipe. With this in mind, I put EatingWell’s Spicy Tofu Hotpot on the menu and I am definitely intrigued. After reading the comments, I foolishly tried udon noodles instead of fresh lo mein. The noodles required more cooking than the recipe called for so the broth-to-noodle ratio was lower than it should have been. Beyond that, the flavors were simply splendid. I’m definitely going to retry this one, but next time I’m going to track down the proper noods.

To have an excuse to devour mass amounts of kale this week, I decided to try out a variation of Vegetarian Times’ Crunchy Green Tahini Salad. I blended up a dressing made of lemon juice, olive oil, tahini, garlic, Bragg Liquid Aminos and honey. Once smooth, I tossed it in my largest bowl with chopped kale, parsley, roasted red potatoes, sliced red pepper, dried cranberries, sunflower seeds and avocado. Filling and delicious!

After last night’s fried fish, I decided to lighten things up a bit with Good Eats’ Curried Split Pea Soup. I sweat some diced onion and garlic with some butter in my dutch oven before adding the dried green split peas, chicken broth and a heaping tablespoon of curry powder. After things simmered for a while, I added a little ground black pepper and cayenne pepper to finish the flavors off before having some fun with my stick blender. Alton Brown never fails to disappoint. I definitely went back for seconds.

Tilapia was on sale today so I decided to try a new tilapia recipe tonight. My inner fatty took control as I made this week’s menu and threw EatingWell’s Baja-Battered Fish on the list. I blended together a beer batter consisting of Charleville’s Half Wit Wheat, all purpose flour, whole wheat pastry flour, salt, pepper, oregano, dry mustard and cayenne pepper. After tossing pieces of the tilapia in the batter I fried ‘em up in my cast iron skillet. Topped with some fresh tomato and avocado salsa, these tacos were fantastic!

To give my grill a little more love this week, I put EatingWell’s Tandoori Tofu on the menu. I spiced up some extra-virgin olive oil in a hot skillet with some cayenne pepper, minced garlic, cumin, coriander, turmeric, salt and lime juice then brushed it on some slabs of tofu. I cross grilled the tofu then paired it with some marinaded veggie kabobs and a quick sauce made of plain yogurt and the leftover oil. I’m satisfied, but next time I think I’ll make a few adjustments.

Ever since I found Herbivoracious.com, I’ve wanted to try out one of Michael Natkin's recipes, but most are quite intimidating. This week, I decided to man up and try one of his simpler recipes, Herbivoracious’ Eggplant Parmesan, and it was outstanding!! I stayed true to the recipe except I added a bit of crushed red pepper to the sauce and I used smoked mozzarella instead of plain.

It may have been hot today, but it sure was CHIILI tonight! I threw together my favorite variation of one of my favorite recipes for dinner tonight: EatingWell’s Sweet Potato & Black Bean Chili. Instead of ground chipotle chili, I use one and a half whole chipotle peppers soaked in adobo sauce and instead of plain canned tomatoes, I use fire roasted tomatoes with chipotle chilis in adobo sauce. Together, those two additives make a fiery hot veggie chili that only gets better over night. In other words, I’m looking forward to tomorrow’s lunch.

My grill has been feeling a bit neglected since I stopped our ‘Sunday Steaks’ tradition last year, so I gave it some love tonight by putting together EatingWell’s Plank-Grilled Sweet Soy Salmon. While a cedar plank soaked in the sink, I soaked a couple salmon fillets in a marinade of ginger, sugar, scallions, mirin, white wine and soy sauce. After about 20 minutes on the grill, the fish was ready and deeelicious. I’ll definitely use this marinade again.
